systeminfo: AVX = 1 | AVX2 = 1 | AVX512 = 0 | FMA = 1 | NEON = 0 | ARM_FMA = 0 | F16C = 1 | FP16_VA = 0 | WASM_SIMD = 0 | BLAS = 0 | SSE3 = 1 | VSX = 0 |

transcription.text: Okay, so this is the E-wasm breakout session.
That's our logo.
This first time we have shown the logo, please remember it.
If you want to take photos.
We don't have time for that.
Okay, thank you all for coming.
This is all the content we're going to have here.
So I'm going to start with some kind of intro, high-level intro, and what Wasm is, et cetera.
And then we dive a bit deeper into the tooling we have, the languages we have.
After that we go into this really hardcore part of EVMC.
And EVMC is like a connection layer between VMs and clients.
So if you are a client implementer, you should definitely watch that.
Also probably going to deep dive a bit more into the interfaces.
That's the E-I, and that's the way to write contracts in E-wasm.
And then the most important part is the testnet.
So hopefully we're going to have a demo here, and we're going to give you a glimpse how
to use the testnet, which is already live.
Is this still good?
Okay.
So we've planned this part to be roughly 40 minutes, and it's really strict, in length
and time, so we don't have time during those to have questions.
But we did reserve a time, like a 10-minute slot, after these introductory parts, to
have a longer Q&A section.
So please keep your questions to that point.
Then depending on how tired people are, we can take a five-minute break, or we can go
even deeper with the second block.
The second block is going to be a lot of research questions and all the really interesting
things are going to happen there.
And lastly, if we still have time, we're going to have a QA part after that.
Okay, so EVMC was in itself, it's just an introduction.
My name is Alex, or exit on the GitHub, that's more people know me.
I've been working on EVMC for a while, and I also work on Solidity Language Design and
the Compiler.
But first, let's just take a step back, and this is just really just a high-level goal
and vision we want to talk a bit about.
So today, we still say that we're in a VEP 3.0 word, but I don't think we're in VEP 3.0
word yet.
You're kind of liking the 2.5 stage.
And at this stage, we write smart contracts in the language, we write some kind of presentation,
and the client side code like the front-end.
And these are done independently of each other.
And then they are also independently deployed.
And nobody has like any connection between these.
And usually, the person working on the contract versus the person working on the front-end
is a different guy, or a different girl.
And they have -- maybe don't have too much connection between the two parts, so it's
not really integrated.
But I think in VEP 3, all of this should be way more seamless than it is today.
And I think that this is like an idea, how this could look like.
So basically, if you look at this, this would be like the DAP from the front-end on.
And there's one single part called the transfer function, which is only part which requires
consensus.
So I have marked that with consensus.
And if you consider this screen, then if you have this in an ID or whatever, at deployment
time, all the compiler and everything will know that this is only part which requires
consensus, that's only part which is going to get to the blockchain, and everything else
stays outside.
The benefits we have here is you see all the data and everything in one block.
You don't have to make these decisions, you know, where is the consensus level data,
where is the front-end data.
And hopefully, it will be a much easier decision to see what belongs where.
Because right now, we do a lot of duplication.
And I think WebAssembly can help a lot in this.
There are already a couple of tools which try to achieve the same thing.
I think it's a big, familiar presentation about Luna, I think Luna is the name, which
has similar goals, but we try to get to there from a different angle.
Now this is just like a high-level, you know, future vision.
But what we are focusing here today on is only the consensus layer.
And how do we get WebAssembly into that consensus layer?
So what it was and was and is a executable binary format designed for the web.
It is designed to be highly performant.
It really models a regular computer.
And basically, if we take a step back, how WebAssembly came into existence, it starts
with the web itself.
So we had JavaScript first to create, you know, any kind of code, which evolved into
Web 2.0 with a way more JavaScript.
And the people started to use other tools like MScripten to compile non-JavaScript code
into JavaScript.
But that was quite slow because JavaScript wasn't designed for this.
So there was this other step called ASMGS, which the JavaScript engines could detect
certain patterns, which are ASMGS patterns, and optimize those.
Now we can optimize this even more by introducing WebAssembly.
We don't need these special patterns.
So that's where this reason WebAssembly came into existence to improve the web.
As a result, WebAssembly itself is designed to support a lot of languages.
It is really low level and a lot of languages supporting it.
There's this awesome WASM-LANG-S repo, which lists pretty much all of them.
They're like 28 today, but with various, you know, various level of integration.
C and Rust would be the best ones today.
But GoHaskill and AssemblyScript are also usable.
As it originates from the web, it is supported by all major browsers.
But ourselves should not focus on the web right now.
We are only focusing about the consensus layer.
And in the consensus layer, we don't want to use any of the web engines.
And we are lucky because there are a lot of other WASM implementations.
We don't have to use web browsers to run WASM.
There are a couple of implementations in C. There's implementation in Rust by parity.
There's implementation in Go.
So we don't have to rely on all this browser-specific toolkit.
So wait, it kind of sounds like Java and JVM, right?
It is kind of, but it isn't fully.
One main difference is Java wasn't designed for the web.
It was designed before the web.
And it was tightly coupled with the language with Java itself.
So as a result, it really had high level features.
They didn't have like a low level abstraction.
It has these high level features, which tightly coupled it with Java's language.
Now we don't have any of these in WASM.
But WASM is designed to be extensible.
So WASM can actually turn into what the JVM is doing.
So one quick example I want to give you here is garbage collection.
Today there's like no WASM level support for garbage collection.
And that means if you compile a language which requires garbage collection,
all this garbage collection helps record going to be in the output.
As a result, it will be big and it will be slow.
But since WASM is designed to be extensible and anybody can propose extensions to it,
their proposals to add WASM level support for garbage collection.
So maybe that will happen.
And maybe we get closer to all these features Java has.
But we, at the consensus layer, are not forced to take these new features.
We can stay with the core level of functional TVM today.
OK, let's talk a tiny bit about the EVM itself.
EVM had different design rules and different goals when it was designed.
It is really focusing on cryptography.
It doesn't really model a regular computer.
I believe EVM really has its origins in Bitcoin script, which is only focused on cryptography.
And public keys, hashing, all of that is slow.
And we don't really need a lot of these things.
I think the reason EVM is kind of slow could be summarizing these two points.
It is 256-bit focused.
So that means all the instructions handle data with 256-bit precision.
We do calculations with 256-bit precision.
And we don't need that in most of the time.
It also makes us high-end level features, which probably is not a good idea.
Now, I don't want to go too deep into EVM here.
But we're going to have, after this two-hour session, we're going to have a panel on EVM.
So I encourage you guys to stay for that and learn more about EVM, the past, present,
and future of the EVM.
But the EVM itself does have one big benefit.
It is kind of small, kind of easy to implement and easy to comprehend.
A single person can easily write an EVM interpreter and grasp the entire EVM specification.
I think the same kind applies to Wasm, but it wasn't specification.
It is a proper specification.
So it is long and is extensive and explains every single edge case.
There's no such specification for the EVM.
So if you look at the EVM spec, it looks small and simple.
But I don't think they differ that much.
Paul will talk more about this in the second part of the session.
OK, finally, we reached EVM.
So what is EVM?
We are trying to marry Wasm and Ethereum together.
But EVM is really just Wasm.
We didn't have to change anything in it.
And that's the beauty of the design of extensibility it has.
So basically, the extensibility we have to add here is we have to expose the Ethereum
state access and modification and access features into WebAssembly.
And that can be done without changing WebAssembly because WebAssembly is designed to have a way
to import external calls and re-exposing all these features as external calls to the Wasm
bytecode.
That being said, we don't want like regular Wasm bytecode to be deployed.
We do want to verify that the bytecode complies to certain rules we want to enforce.
The good news is, though, that you can use a regular compiler with supports Wasm and you
can compile the code with that.
You don't need any change there.
And most of the time, you don't even need any kind of post-processing.
But we do have to ensure that nothing goes wrong in a consensus setting in a blockchain.
So we have this verification step.
When somebody is deploying Wasm bytecode, we run it to another contract, which we call
the central contract.
And this contract is looking up certain features which shouldn't be used in Wasm bytecode.
So one feature which always comes up and which is the major one we have to restrict
is floating point numbers.
We cannot deal with floating point numbers right now in a consensus setting.
So we just reject any contract which uses floating point.
But in most of the languages, you don't have to use floating point anyway.
For contracts, this is not a problem.
The other big part we have to do during this deployment process is to inject metering into
WebAssembly.
The reason for that is we don't want to have specific Wasm VMs which do runtime metering.
We still want to use generic Wasm VMs or at least have the ability to use generic Wasm
VMs.
That being said, I do believe that we have to have specific Wasm VM implementations in
our nodes which are really designed to work in this environment.
But they are still compatible with Wasm bytecode.
Some of the high level design goals we have followed are it's really just to have an
extensible foundation for code execution.
And it wasn't just kind of like a blueprint for computational describing computation.
So you can take this Wasm blueprint and you can translate it to local machine code.
That's how it's designed.
So I think it's a really good foundation for this.
We're also trying to tap into a very bigger ecosystem here, into more languages, but more
importantly, a lot of more tooling, especially regarding security, analysis, all the data
and et cetera.
This point of reducing complexity in Ethereum and how if we are introducing this kind of
more complicated thing, at least some people claim it's kind of more complicated, but there
are ways to reduce the complexity in Ethereum by having Wasm.
So one example here I want to highlight is precompies.
So today with precompies, every single client has to implement precompies themselves.
With Wasm, you could just supply a single implementation of the precompie in Wasm itself
and have it in each of the clients.
That's less good to be written.
But one really interesting thing which came up before DevCon had this warm summit, Jules
from the Lite, the Lite client protocol.
What is alias and for?
But that's the Lite Ethereum, whatever.
But he's the Lite client protocol person.
He's designing the entire Lite client protocol for Ethereum.
He came up with this idea to use Wasm in there.
The problem he's facing is in the Lite client protocol, you have to make, say you make one
query to get like a hash and then you receive more data and then you have to make subsequent
queries.
So it bubbles up into a lot of queries.
So what you could do is submit a computation in Wasm to note that the note executes at computation
and gives you back all the results.
So you don't need all this data exchange.
You can get the note to get you the data you need exactly.
So I think that's really interesting direction we could go.
But lastly, a really important point is with Wasm, we do get the better interaction with
other blockchains.
So I'm going to expand on those a bit later.
So with the languages itself, we are tapping into a bigger pool of languages.
That being said, we still want to support Solidity.
So the Solidity team is working on having Wasm output and hopefully that's going to happen
early, mid-next year.
No commitments here though.
But today we already have a lot of the tooling for Wasm in Rust because Rust is like the most
mature language you have tooling for Wasm.
But there's this last thing which we also going to touch on today is assembly script,
which is a language similar to JavaScript.
And it is -- we are working on a framework in assembly script to write contracts in.
So it's really looks like JavaScript, it is easy to use, and it's compiling to Wasm.
Just a few notes about other blockchains, a lot of other blockchains using or considering
Wasm.
And if we also do use Wasm, we're going to have way more options to -- sorry, to have
code shared between all of them.
So I think that's super exciting.
Okay.
Just two more things to mention.
Because we haven't really mentioned like backwards compatibility.
So we have this tool called RunVM, which is an EVM interpreter compiled to Wasm.
And you can use this in a entirely Wasm-only client.
And you can run EVM bytecode on this Wasm-only client.
Why EVM is a similar tool, but instead of having an interpreter, it is compiling EVM
to Wasm bytecode.
Now these are early prototypes.
So if anybody is interested in working on these really good projects, please talk to us.
So the next steps we have now is we're launching a test net.
And then we're trying to get all of this into the mainnet.
But we cannot do that at once.
So we're trying to get a subset of precompiled only support into the mainnet.
And then I have the entirety of EVM in the mainnet.
Even though it's set like a goal number four, I think, chessper/e2.0/serenity work going
to happen parallel to all of this.
So that was the intro.
Please check these back and all the code we have.
Show them Gitter, create Dapps, and talk to us.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
Sorry, I didn't sort of do an intro in the beginning.
That was Alex Bergs-Hossi.
He's our team lead.
One more round of applause for Alex.

All right.
Up next.
I think we're going to do demos of some of the language tooling that we've built.
Paul, are you up first?
Obviously, one of the nice things we get with the Ewasm tool chain is the ability to
develop smart contracts in a whole host of different programming languages.
Alex, a moment ago, mentioned some of them.
These include Rust, CC++, AssemblyScript.
We're going to do quick demos of two or three of these right now.
And as a first framework for doing that, Alex created something called the WRC20 challenge.
The W refers to Wasm.
And it was just a challenge that we put out there a few months ago to build a simple ERC20
style contract, like a token contract, using the various languages.
We've had implementations done in eight or nine languages so far.
I think you can find this in our GitHub repository.
GitHub.com/Ewasm if you're interested in contributing one.
And Paul's going to do CC++, right?
Yes.
Do you hear a mic?
Can you hear me?
Can you hear me?
Great.
Yes, we had this WRC20 challenge to implement ERC20.
And I wanted to implement it in C and C++.
So I think most engineers-- many engineers learn C as an undergrad.
And C++ is ubiquitous.
And people are talking about these languages like Rust and AssemblyScript.
But I'm sort of naive.
And I'm stuck in my ways.
And I like C and C++.
So that's why I wrote it in C or C++.
So anyway, I found some--
anyway, this is just a gist of the code.
Boy, I don't know.
Some reverse byte stuff.
And I wasn't really--
I don't know what to really say.
We have some functions that we were to implement.
And I implemented them.
And this is how--
I know this is a lot to just--
I don't know how I'm supposed to explain this in five minutes.
But anyway, this is the smart contract in C and C for C++.
And we're hoping that if we're going to onboard hundreds
of thousands, millions of people, a lot of C and C++ programmers

So maybe we should give them the tools to do it.
And some make stuff.

But there are some problems.

But there are some people writing tools
to do this kind of thing.
Elaine, can you come?
And also I wanted to show another implementation of WRC-20.
I'm not a meck person.
That's why.
Oh boy.
[LAUGHTER]
OK, so if you don't-- so C is one option.
C++ is one option.
But if you want to hand write it in a web assembly,
you can do this.
So this is my version.
And I think this is the shortest version of the WRC-20,
the most efficient one.
And if you're going to use it, this might be the best one.
It's like 180 lines of web assembly code.

No.

Maybe you won't trust it.
But I don't know.
180 lines, isn't-- beg your pardon?
Oh, OK, Elaine.
Oh, yes.

If you go to--
[INAUDIBLE]
Right, so we have a WRC-20 examples repository here.
It's uwasm/wrc-20 examples.
And right now there's an issue open.
And you can see, I think, most of them are listed here.
So we have Rust.
We have assembly script, which I'll show you in a sec.
We have Nim, which is very cool.
C++, handwritten web assembly.
I think there may be a couple of others as well.
Is that-- are you--

Cool.
Thanks, Paul.
[APPLAUSE]
All right, I'm going to show you guys
what the assembly script one looks like now.
So I initially came up with a really clever name for this talk,
smart contracts in JavaScript.
No, really, almost.
Let me explain what I mean by that.
So first, what is--
sorry, what is assembly script?
So assembly script is a subset of TypeScript, which I'm sure
many of you are familiar with.
TypeScript is a strictly typed superset of JavaScript.
And types are good for a whole host of reasons
we believe they produce better code.
It's a better programming paradigm.
And in particular, in sort of mission critical applications,
like we're writing on Ethereum, we
think that the types go a long way to, like I said,
writing better, more secure, better performance code as well.
And on top of all that, of course, web assembly itself
is strictly typed.
So yeah, so there's a really cool project called assembly
script, which allows you to write in a language which looks
and feels a lot like JavaScript, or of course, TypeScript,
if you've used it, and compile that down to web assembly.
And so from my perspective, I have nothing against domain
specific languages, like Solidity and Viper
and all the other great ones.
I think that they're very important.
They've gotten us quite far, and they'll
have a role in the Ethereum ecosystem for some time to come.
However, my personal sort of goal for Ethereum
is I want to see millions of people developing applications
on Ethereum.
And personally, I don't believe that the way we get there
is by requiring people to learn brand new programming
languages and brand new programming paradigms from scratch.
Let me just go over this point one more time,
because I think it's important.
There's a huge advantage to doing that.
If you're writing mission critical code,
if you're writing a piece of wallet software, by all means,
do it in Solidity, do it in Viper, learn EVM,
get that code audited.
I don't want that process to change.
But if you're building something for fun,
if you're building a toy, if you're hacking at a hackathon,
I really think that having something that, as I said,
looks and feels like JavaScript and uses existing JavaScript
tooling, tools like NVM and Yarn, et cetera, NPM, et cetera,
will go a long way towards opening the Ethereum ecosystem
to millions of developers who are very familiar with those tools.
So that's my personal motivation for working on AssemblyScript.
So I'm just going to-- this is, as Paul said a moment ago,
this is a lightning talk.
I'm just going to super quickly show you what this looks like.
And the first thing I'm going to show you here
is my WRC20 example code.
So this works.
This is AssemblyScript.
It's valid.
It compiles.
It runs.
We've deployed it on the test net.
And I'm sorry if that font size is not super large.
I don't think I can easily increase it.
But hopefully, you guys can get a sense of this.
It's kind of funny.
It looks sort of like JavaScript.
It kind of has JavaScript syntax.
But we've got the strict types of TypeScript.
And then we've got stuff which looks and feels a bit like Assembly.
So what's going on here is we have a single main function,
which is the entry point.
And what you see with this switch here and these sort of hexadecimal
strings, this is a simplified version of ABI.
So we've manually implemented this.
The main function receives a call.
And it sort of unpacks the first few bytes
and uses that to figure out which function is being called.
And I think I have the do balance function over here,
which is the one that returns the current balance.
And you see things which are basically more or less map one
to one to EVM operations.
So things like get call data size, call data copy.
We're also manually managing memory.
We're loading things into pointers and stuff.
I think I have another one here.
This is the do transfer function.
So again, this kind of reads the input data,
gets the length of it reads the input data,
and allocates memory, moves pointers around, et cetera.
And then there's no return, because what has to happen
is it has to store the return value into a pointer.
So this is a step in the right direction,
but this is not exactly the way I want to write code.
And so I want to show you this is what it will look like.
And this should look and feel a lot more like JavaScript,
like modern JavaScript.
We have some abstracted classes, things like a contract.
We have decorators.
So we use an Ewazim decorator to indicate
that this class is the entry point in this code.
We use a simple store decorator.
So this looks and feels a little bit more like solidity.
It's inspired by solidity.
We have things like maps.
And look how much less code this is.
Look how much more readable this is.
Get balance, set balance, or a single line.
The transfer code should be pretty clear.
So this is the direction we're going.
The first part here, as I said, this works.
This compiles.
This code is in that WRC20 examples directory
that I showed you a moment ago.
This is like halfway there.
I've been working on this myself and could definitely use help.
So this is under the EtherTS organization on GitHub,
github.com/etherts.
TS being TypeScript.
We're trying to build out some more TypeScript tooling.
Yeah, I was going to do a quick live demo of showing you
how easy it is to initialize this.
You can just install a single npm module.
You run a single command.
And you've got the framework.
But I think we're running short on time.
So let's go on to our next talk.
Thank you.

So up next we have Pavel.
So Pavel is a member of the Ewasm team.
He is also on the Aleaf team.
And he's going to talk to you about EVMC.
Hello.
Does it work already?
Yeah, OK.
Hello, everyone.
I'm C++ developer within Ethereum Foundation.
And one of the project I was working for some time
is called EVMC.
I would try to explain with it and give some quick updates
what has happened in the project recently.
And well, skip the lot.
OK, here we go.
And in the second part of this presentation,
I'd like to go from this EVMC and through EVM as well,
go back to Ewasm and explain some design decisions we made
and where they come from.
Oh, sorry about that.
OK, so let's start with this EVMC.
This is a project that has mostly one go.
And it wants to define the API in the classical sense
of the way the EVM implementation
can communicate with the full Ethereum client
and how we call it here.
We call it a host.
So it describes RASSE functions, the both sides
of this equation has to implement.
So on the host side, we require some functions, some methods.
The client has to provide the EVM execution.
And on the VM side, we just define
what are the entry points for execution
and how the VM should be created and how
it can be used by Ethereum client implementations.
And if we can focus on the host methods that are there,
there are 12 of them.
And most of these basic definitions
are written in C code.
However, I decided to show you an example of how
this method looks like, taking the go part of the project.
You don't need to read it all.
I wanted to show how complex it is
to enable this EVM support in Ethereum client implementation.
And so to explain where it was, it's all this picture.
So it's not so--
I mean, it seems it's a completely different execution engine.
But EVM C actually doesn't care about the execution itself.
It defines what actually data has to be provided
to the execution.
So this project was started more or less the same time
the USM idea was brought up to the Ethereum community.
But it didn't have the USM in mind.
But it turned out you can also implement
the USM execution engine and use exactly the same API
to bring USM to Ethereum clients.
And here is one of the examples that actually support EVM C
from the beginning.
And it's fully compatible with any Ethereum client
that actually has also the EVM support in the bank.
So within this EVM C project, they also
try to have language bindings directly inside the project.
And we started-- well, the first one
was the Python prototype of that to figure out
if Python being scripting language.
Is it the C API is good enough to have Python support?
And that worked very well.
But now we have Go support ready to be used.
And Gef is using that.
That's Go bindings in the Go Ethereum project.
And I hope there will be more.
But mostly, I try to keep them inside the project
to be tested with all the changes we're making there.
And just before DevCon, there was release 6.0.0 of EVM C.
We're using semantic versioning for that.
And also, we describe a number called
ABI version, which is the first number of the full version.
And this number is exposed to the implementation
to check for basic compatibility, especially
when we use dynamic loaded libraries for deployment.
And at the current moment, I'll have the C++ implementation
of Ethereum client and Gef within the pre-quest
that was submitted.
Suppose EVM C. And on the VM side,
we have Aleff interpreter, which is part of Aleff product.
And also, here, I'd suppose that currently.
And there is a node that actually uses this Gef
plus Aleff interpreter combination
that it's fully production ready and can be used
in the mainnet.
I have one node running myself.
And we're using Gef and here a combination
to run the Ewals and TestNet.
And some of the plans, but I changed it to Wishes
because there's no commitment to that.
It kind of works in the reactive way.
So if you would like to have to bring this support
to your projects or you need some other language bindings,
pre-sexpress this needs, and we're happy to have.
And this is a way when you can learn more about the project
where you can find the implementation.
There are implementation guides, both for VM side
and for host side, some examples and chat room
when we are available.
So from that, I would like to go to the second part of this talk
and spend very little time on explaining
how this affects Ewals and Design, to some sense.
So I'd like to put your attention on three aspects
of starting with the VM.
There are these kind of special opcodes there
that annoys many people.
But how they map-- and I would like
to explain how they map to EVMC design and both the Ewals
and Design.
So these special instructions I mean
are some instructions that allows
you from the contract execution to access Ethereum state
and some other environment information about what's
going on currently on the blockchain.
So you are allowed to put some data in this database
called Storage, read data from there,
and check balances of other accounts and many other things.
And just for this example, I will focus on this S-load and S-store.
And so because this storage access is required
for contract execution, but it's not about the execution itself,
it's a way to access some data that is outside of this virtual machine
that it's conducting execution.
So for example, in EVMC and Design, we have to provide that.
So this is like one of the required methods
the host has to implement to allow contracts to access that.
And we cannot provide this data upfront because that would be--
I mean, we don't know which exactly portion of data
would be needed for execution.
So this is also taken from goal bindings of EVMC.

And when we go to Ewasm and precisely to this Ethereum environment interface,
this is a part of Ewasm that tries to describe very similar aspect of that.

that are specific to Ethereum.

specify a required for execution.

will have a set of these.

need this function provided by the environment I'm running

So what I've done is I've hooked into their compiler

So if you know anything about the way compilers work,
you have a tokenized step and you have parsing and tokenizing
and then you have a compilation step.
And then-- so in between those two,
it hands us the AST, which is the abstract syntax tree.
And we can kind of move things around.
So for example, there were decorators like that
at Uwasm decorators.
So in the transform step, we can grab that
and we can then insert things like the init code
that we need into the tree.
And then that gets passed back to the assembly script
compiler and that gets compiled down to Wasm code.
So that's just a high level overview of how this works.
